title: A Case of Neuromyelitis Optica: A 32-Year-Old Female with Severe Visual Disturbances and Lower Limb Weakness
clinical_history: A 32-year-old female, Sarah, presented with a 2-week history of progressive visual disturbances, including blurred vision and painful eye movements. She reported difficulty walking due to lower limb weakness and numbness in both legs. The symptoms started with a sudden loss of vision in her right eye, which improved over a few days, but then she developed numbness and weakness in her lower limbs. She also complained of severe back pain and urinary retention.

nprs.affected_area: Severe visual disturbances and eye pain

aggrevating_factors: Prolonged walking, standing, or sitting; neck flexion or extension
picture: A 24-hour picture showing a person with visual disturbances, lower limb weakness, and back pain
past_history: History of optic neuritis in the left eye 5 years ago, which resolved with treatment
medical_history: Generally healthy, but has a history of autoimmune disorders in the family
personal_history: Married with two young children; works as a part-time teacher
imaging: MRI showing extensive lesions in the spinal cord and optic nerves
